He say, “One and one and one is three”

Pקרישפדthis line as a reference to John, Paul and George. The next line is then about Ringo, as the drummer is hid at the back. Also, the drummer for the beatles before Ringo was Pete Best who always believed that he was replaced because he was too good looking and the was upstaging John.
[Verse 4]

There is an alternate theory that each verse in the song refers to one of the Beatles. In this case, Paul thinking of leaving the group, making them three. He is also the most good-looking of the Beatles, yet also the most private, and the hardest one to “see into”.
[Verse 2]

There is an alternate theory that each verse in the song refers to one of the Beatles. In this case, Ringo  bangs on the drums like a chimpanzee, and comes out with pithy sayings the oter beatles called “Ringoisms”, like “It’s a Hard Day’s Night”, “Tomorrow Never Knows” and “I know you, you know me”
[Verse 1]

There is an alternate theory that each verse in the song refers to one of the Beatles. In this case, George was the ‘holy roller" with the far-out eyeballs, who did what he pleased, including quitting the Beatles earlier in the year.
He one spinal cracker
This line refers to when Lennon crashed his Austin Maxi on July 1st 1969, with a pregnant Yoko Ono in the passenger seat; John got away with 17 stitches, Yoko suffered a back injury.
He one holy roller

“Holy Roller” is a term used to describe members of fundamentalist, evangelical Christian groups who focus on frenzied worship. It may be considered to be offensive or derogatory. Some of these denominations are famous for speaking in tongues or entering trances, known as being “in the spirit.”

This line is characterizing the song’s subject as energetic—almost frantically spiritual. This meshes well with the previous mention of “ju-ju eyeballs”; perhaps the man is a voodoo mystic.

Shoot me
 Shoot me
 Shoot me
 Shoot me

John Lennon can be heard whispering the words “shoot me” repeatedly, in time with the first two notes of the bass line. This continues throughout the song whenever the opening bass riff is repeated.

“Shoot me” is a possible reference to shooting up heroin—which Lennon and Yoko Ono were heavy users of at the time. The words can clearly be heard in this isolated track:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hPpmevRcsck

These lines became a part of the “Paul is Dead” conspiracy, with some purporting that the voice is actually the “fake” McCartney asking to be shot.
Gumboot

A South African Zulu dance where they wear WELLINGTONS!

The “gumboot” dance is a kind of rhythmic variation of tap, where the aesthetic appearance is secondary to the musicality. The entire body becomes a musical instrument.
He bag production,
Bag production refers to John and Yoko’s theory of Bagism; That if everyone was in a large bag that covered their features there would be no sexism, racism or prejudice.
He got muddy water, he one mojo filter

Refers to Muddy Waters' “Got My Mojo Workin'”.

Linking back to the “ju-ju” reference, a mojo is a voodoo charm – although it’s also slang for morphine. Around the time the song was recorded, Lennon and Ono were addicted to heroin.

Additionally, The Mojos were a Merseybeat group from Liverpool, and one of the Beatles’ early musical rivals. Like the Beatles, they were popular at the Star-Club in Hamburg. The Mojos only enjoyed limited success on an national level, with “Everything’s Alright” peaking at #9 on the British Charts in 1964.   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o8tMGdUrpLw
